citations.narrative:
The Record of Animals on hand (acquisition and disposition records) seen at time of inspection was not current or
complete. Since 9/11/2024, additional animals have been acquired and more have been sold and/or disposed of, per the
licensee, without documentation as follows:
• Acquisitions: two blackbucks, one Scottish highland, one bison, four llamas, two water buffalos, and one zebra.
• Dispositions: one bison, two oryx, one llama, three zebras, and three budgies.
Accurate and complete acquisition and disposition records are necessary to allow for medical and legal tracking of the
animals. The facility shall ensure that they make, keep, and maintain records that fully and correctly disclose all the
required information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or in their possession or which
are transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal
while in his or her possession.
Corrected at the time of inspection.
Correct by: November 30, 2024.

The facility is not ensuring that animals are handled with minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public. At the time
of inspection, inspectors observed an eland placing its head inside a public vehicle as a result of the public feeding the
animal from inside the vehicle, against the facility’s posted rules. An attendant was either not present or did not intervene.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals and
the public. When animals place their heads inside guest's personal vehicles, there is more than minimal risk of harm to
the animal and to the public. The licensee must ensure that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the
animal and to the public.
Correct by December 1, 2024.

The facility did not have an attendant present when the public was allowed to have contact with regulated animals as
follows:
• Inspectors observed visitors failing to follow park rules such as only feeding animals by holding food buckets outside the
window, and either an attendant was not present to enforce the rules, or the attendant did not take responsibility for
enforcing the rules.
• At the petting zoo area, inspectors observed patrons feeding and/or touching llamas, pigs, and goats in a barnyard
without a readily identifiable employee or attendant present.
• At the giraffe feeding station, adults were observed feeding the giraffes lettuce with no attendant present.
• At the walk-in budgie aviary, three patrons were observed entering and exiting the aviary with no attendant present in
the aviary.
Lack of employee oversight of direct interactions between the animals and the visitors may lead to injury to the humans
and/or injury or distress to the animals. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must
be present at all times during periods of public contact.

The giraffe barn is not maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. The indoor barn for the giraffes has a
hanging exhaust fan cord located approximately 11 feet from the ground. The taller giraffe is approximately 12 feet tall
with its mouth located at about 11 feet. The shorter giraffe is approximately 11 feet tall. The cord is routed through the wall
and the outlet isn’t visible from inside the barn. The licensee states that the fan is not currently in use but has been
powered on and used during warmer weather as recently as this past summer season (since the last inspection). While
the outlet itself is protected from the giraffes, the fan’s electrical cord is hanging within reach of the giraffes. The cord is
unprotected, risking chewing or pulling with the giraffe’s long prehensile tongue (average length is 18-20 inches), and is
not secured against the wall, risking potential entanglement with their ossicones and/or head. Inspectors observed the
taller giraffe nibbling at the wooden boards separating the stalls in the barn. Per the licensee, the giraffes have been
chewing on parts of the barn as evidenced by multiple chew marks along the length of the top of the wooden wall
separating the stalls, as well as the top of and sides of the sliding wooden gate. These chew marks highlight the oral
exploratory nature of these giraffes. Unsecured and unprotected electrical cords within reach of the animal can cause
entanglement, injury, or possibly electrocution to the animals. The housing facility must be maintained to protect the
animals from injury.
Correct by November 30, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection beginning 11/15/2024, and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. This inspection was conducted with the licensees on 11/15/2024 and a final exit
briefing for the items included in this report was conducted on 11/25/2024.
Additional Inspectors:
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The Record of Animals on hand (acquisition and disposition records) seen at time of inspection was not current or 
complete. Since 9/11/2024, additional animals have been acquired and more have been sold and/or disposed of, per the

• Acquisitions: two blackbucks, one Scottish highland, one bison, four llamas, two water buffalos, and one zebra.  
• Dispositions: one bison, two oryx, one llama, three zebras, and three budgies.  
Accurate and complete acquisition and disposition records are necessary to allow for medical and legal tracking of the

required information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or in their possession or which 
are transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal 
while in his or her possession. 
Corrected at the time of inspection.

2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility is not ensuring that animals are handled with minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public. At the time

animal and to the public.  
Correct by December 1, 2024. 
2.131(d)(2)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals.

The facility did not have an attendant present when the public was allowed to have contact with regulated animals as 
follows:  
• Inspectors observed visitors failing to follow park rules such as only feeding animals by holding food buckets outside the 
window, and either an attendant was not present to enforce the rules, or the attendant did not take responsibility for

Lack of employee oversight of direct interactions between the animals and the visitors may lead to injury to the humans 
and/or injury or distress to the animals. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must 
be present at all times during periods of public contact. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The giraffe barn is not maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. The indoor barn for the giraffes has a 
hanging exhaust fan cord located approximately 11 feet from the ground. The taller giraffe is approximately 12 feet tall

animals from injury.  
Correct by November 30, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection beginning 11/15/2024, and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. This inspection was conducted with the licensees on 11/15/2024 and a final exit 
briefing for the items included in this report was conducted on 11/25/2024.

Additional Inspectors: 
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
